Review Insight into demand-driven preparation of single-atomic mediators for lithium–sulfur batteries Miaoyu Lu a 1 Yifan Ding a 1 Zaikun Xue a b 1 Ziang Chen a Yuhan Zou a Jingyu Sun a b ⁎ a College of Energy, Soochow Institute for Energy and Materials Innovations, Key Laboratory for Advanced Carbon Materials and Wearable Energy Technologies of Jiangsu Province, Soochow University, Suzhou 215006, Jiangsu, China College of Energy Soochow Institute for Energy and Materials Innovations Key Laboratory for Advanced Carbon Materials and Wearable Energy Technologies of Jiangsu Province Soochow University Suzhou Jiangsu 215006 China College of Energy, Soochow Institute for Energy and Materials Innovations, Key Laboratory for Advanced Carbon Materials and Wearable Energy Technologies of Jiangsu Province, Soochow University, Suzhou 215006, Jiangsu, China b Beijing Graphene Institute, Beijing 100095, China Beijing Graphene Institute Beijing 100095 China Beijing Graphene Institute, Beijing 100095, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract This review summarizes application-oriented design philosophy of single-atomic mediators for Li–S batteries and their emerging synthetic strategies, which is represented by chemical vapor deposition route. Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries have attracted considerable attention as one of the most appealing energy storage systems. Strenuous efforts have been devoted to tackling the tremendous challenges, mainly pertaining to the severe shuttle effect, sluggish redox kinetics and lithium dendritic growth. Single-atomic mediators as promising candidates exhibit impressive performance in addressing these intractable issues. Related research often utilizes a trial-and-error approach, proposing solutions to fabricate single-atomic materials with diversified features. However, comprehensive review articles especially targeting demand-driven preparation are still in a nascent stage. Inspired by these considerations, this review summarizes the design of single-atomic mediators based on the application case-studies in Li–S batteries and other metal–sulfur systems. Emerging preparation routes represented by chemical vapor deposition technology are introduced in a demand-oriented classification. Finally, future research directions are proposed to foster the advancement of single-atomic mediators in Li–S realm. Keywords Single-atom catalyst Lithium–sulfur battery Chemical vapor deposition Demand-driven preparation 1 Introduction With the rapid consumption of fossil energy and the consequent environmental problems, it is urgent to develop sustainable energy storage solutions [1]. Though lithium-ion batteries have been commercialized [2], the mediocre energy density output of practical cells (∼200 W h kg−1) is still insufficient to meet the expanding demands, making the exploration of emerging energy storage systems of key significance [3]. Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries have captured widespread attention because of their high theoretical energy density of 2600 W h kg−1 [4,5]. A typical Li–S battery consists of active sulfur cathode, electrolyte, separator and lithium metal anode. The abundant resource reserves could significantly cut the cost of commercial production of Li–S batteries [6]. Additionally, no toxic and hazardous substances, such as lead and hydrargyrum, are involved in the reactions. These advantages render the Li–S batteries appealing as high-energy–density systems [7,8]. Nevertheless, thorny issues still hamper the commercial applications of Li–S batteries (Fig. 1 ). The development of Li–S batteries remains a grand challenge in terms of cell performance [7,9,10]. Rather, such a goal is mainly hindered by the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) [11–13]. The dissolution of LiPSs in the electrolyte yields irreversible capacity degradation [14]. The sluggish redox journey also impedes the rate performances of the battery [9,15,16]. In parallel, the anode of Li–S batteries, similar to those applying lithium metal as anode, is subject to uncontrolled growth of lithium dendrites [17]. Along with this, there is a density gap between sulfur and the discharge product Li2S. Such a difference could trigger drastic volume changes in the cathode, possibly inducing the electrode collapse [18–20]. In response to these issues, Nazar's group [21] proposed the use of low-cost transition metal oxide MnO2 as an effective polysulfide mediator. Chung et al. [22] demonstrated the effective suppression of shuttle effect by modifying the separator with coating conductive carbon black. There is no doubt that increasing the active specific surface area of catalysts can upgrade the catalytic performance [23]. Based on this, many efforts have been devoted to scaling down the size of catalysts from clusters to nanometer sized particulates, even to isolated atomic dispersions [24–26]. Existed in the form of separate atoms, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have become a research hotspot in recent years on account of 100% atom utilization and impressive catalytic activity per unit mass. SACs demonstrate remarkable performance in oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) [27–29], oxygen evolution reactions (OER) [30,31], hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) [32] and other aspects of catalytic reactions [33–35]. In the realm of Li–S batteries, single-atomic mediators have readily shown satisfactory results in expediting reaction kinetics, restricting LiPSs shuttle and inhibiting Li dendrites [26,36,37]. As the demand for single-atomic materials with unique properties has diversified, the development of their preparation technologies requests to be updated [38,39]. Emerging methodologies, represented by chemical vapor deposition (CVD), also commence to exert key advantages in the preparation of functional single-atomic mediators [40,41]. Inspired by these aspects, a comprehensive review detailing the recent advances and future outlooks in this realm is imperative. In this contribution, starting from the mechanistic design of single-atom mediators, their employments in Li–S systems and other related metal–sulfur counterparts are summarized. The case-studies on the preparation of single-atomic materials by CVD are showcased, with a demand-oriented classification and brief introduction to emerging preparation routes. Finally, possible directions in the development of single-atomic mediators in the realm of Li–S batteries are presented. 2 Single-atomic mediators in Li–S battery To cope with the issues in Li–S batteries, single-atomic mediators are widely employed in designing the cathode and anode, as well as modifying the separator. In this section, we analyze the different functions of single-atomic mediators. Meanwhile, we also briefly introduce the employment of single-atomic materials in other metal–sulfur batteries. Finally, we summarize the design rules for single-atomic mediators in Li–S batteries. 2.1 Cathode 2.1.1 Catalytic mechanism Conventional bulk materials are catalytically limited to the surface during the reaction. In contrast, SACs are isolated atoms dispersed at an atomic level, with the catalytic active site fully exposed. Thus, the theoretical utilization of SACs can reach 100%. In addition, the catalytic activity of SACs can be in target tailored by adjusting the substrate support, coordination number and coordination atoms, so as to regulate its electron density and d-band center [42,43]. With the booming employment of SACs in Li–S batteries, the related catalytic mechanisms have been explored in response. Despite the favorable catalytic performance of SACs, explicit design concepts and uniform screening criteria are still in their infancy. The d-p orbital hybridization between single atoms and polysulfide was proposed by Han et al. [44] as a descriptor for screening high-performance SACs for Li–S batteries (Fig. 2 a). The d orbital of a metal atom and the p orbital of sulfur are involved in the adsorption of intermediates. The degree of hybridization affects the electronic structure of the adsorbate, which further exerts influence on the activation process. Based on the crystal field theory, a group of nine transition metal SACs containing different d electron fillings from Sc to Cu were investigated with four nitrogen-atom coordination. According to the orbital symmetry, the d z 2 orbital hybridizes with the p z orbital of sulfur, forming σ and σ* bonds. The two-fold d xz / y z orbital hybridizes with the p x / y orbital, forming two relatively weak π and π* bonds, while d xy and d x 2 - y 2 are considered as non-bonding configurations. Since the metals from Sc to Cu are featured by different numbers of d electrons, the antibonding orbitals π* and σ* are gradually filled as the electron filling proceeds, resulting in a reduced energy splitting between the bonding orbitals (π and σ) and the antibonding orbitals (π* and σ*). Sc is the element with the fewest d electrons, which has a relatively weak ScS bond owing to the larger atomic radius. Accordingly, Ti single atom is selected because of the most efficient d-p orbital hybridization (Fig. 2b). Zhang et al. [45] also suggested that d-p orbital hybridization could be used to probe the mechanism in Li–S catalysis from the perspective of electronic configuration (Fig. 2c). Given the unique electronic structure of SACs, the effect on catalytic activity deserves further investigation. Based on crystal field theory, it was found that the geometric distortion in Nb−N site leads to a transformation of d orbital energy levels, where d xz , d yz and d z 2 energy levels increase, whereas those of d xy and d x 2 - y 2 decrease. Changes in energy levels could give rise to more filling of bonding orbitals by electrons and less filling of antibonding orbitals (Fig. 2d). Enhanced interfacial charge transfer and redox kinetics could be achieved by strengthening the d-p orbital hybridization. It is rather difficult to analyze the catalytic mechanism of SACs for intricate reactions in Li–S batteries. In sulfur reduction reactions, the solid–solid conversion process of Li2S2–Li2S becomes a pivotal rate-determining step because of the slow diffusion and poor contact between the solid–solid phase [47]. The investigation of the catalytic mechanism for this specific step is of importance to enable advanced Li–S systems. In this regard, Yan et al. [46] revealed that the catalytic effect of ferromagnetic single atoms (Fe, Co, Ni) in the Li2S2–Li2S reduction process originates from their spin density and magnetic moments. They found that the d-orbital electronic states of Fe–N4 show an asymmetric distribution according to the partial projected density of states. In contrast, Co–N4 shows weaker asymmetry, while Ni–N4 is devoid of asymmetry. Such a d-orbital asymmetry would cause spin polarization, which provides spin electrons and leads to less antibonding orbital occupation to enhance FeS interactions (Fig. 2e and f). The strengthened FeS bonding would readily facilitate the weakening of SS bonding, thereby promoting the dissociation of Li2S2. 2.1.2 Employment scenario The polysulfide shuttle effect is one of the key challenges within the sulfur cathode [48]. The shuttling of soluble polysulfides between the electrodes during charge/discharge induces low sulfur utilization and rapid capacity degradation [49,50]. Physical adsorption can mitigate the shuttle effect to some extent by mildly anchoring the polysulfide molecules [51]. In contrast, SACs help promote redox kinetics, in addition to effectively suppress the shuttle effect of polysulfides. Based on the high atom utilization and good catalytic activity, it is beneficial to the construction of high-energy Li–S battery. Cobalt atoms embedded in nitrogen-doped graphene (Co−N/G) were proposed by Ji’s group [52] as promising sulfur host materials (Fig. 3 a). In this study, Co atoms are coordinated with N atoms to form atomically dispersed Co mono-atomic centers with Co−N−C structures. Applying Co−N/G material as the sulfur host, the assembled Li–S battery achieves high sulfur utilization even under a sulfur content of 90 wt%, obtaining a specific capacity of 1210 mA h g−1. The cell also exhibits conspicuous cycling stability. With a sulfur loading of 6.0 mg cm−2, the material still delivers an areal capacity of 5.1 mA h cm−2 for more than 100 cycles at 0.2 C, with a capacity decay rate of 0.029% per cycle. Based on the analysis of operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and first-principles calculations, it is found that the catalytic performances of Co − N/G stem from atomically dispersed Co single atoms, which act as bidirectional electrocatalysts to promote the formation and decomposition of Li2S, respectively. This pioneer work offers valuable insights into the development of SACs for sulfur cathode design. Previously reported SACs usually exhibit low mass contents (typically below 5 wt%), as one of the drawbacks lies in their tendency for aggregation [25]. In this case, it is imperative yet challenging to explore the structure-performance relationship of elevated loaded SACs. Ding et al. [53] designed Fe single atoms with a mass loading of 6.32 wt%. This was realized by a diatomite-template strategy to render single-atomic Fe–N2 species dispersed on biomorphic 3D C3N4 support (3DFeSA–CN) (Fig. 3b). As a host material for sulfur cathode, the as-fabricated 3DFeSA–CN effectively mitigate volume changes during charging and discharging and promote ion/electron transport. Meanwhile, such 3D ordered structure also facilitates the adsorption and conversion of LiPSs. This biotemplating strategy is conducive to augmenting the single-atom content and constructing unsaturated coordination environments. The prepared Fe–N2 moiety with unsaturated coordination environment can significantly enhance the chemisorption and catalytic conversion of LiPSs, ultimately promoting redox kinetics and mitigating shuttle effects. Many studies have indicated that the catalytic activity of SACs is related to the coordination environment [56,57]. Tuning the electronic structure of metal center by changing the coordination number and coordination atoms offers a reliable solution [58,59]. SACs are usually coordinated with four nitrogen atoms, with a planar symmetric structure leading to a uniform electron distribution [42,60]. Nevertheless, the optimal adsorption of polysulfides is hard to be achieved in this case. Hence, asymmetric coordination structures are usually constructed to adjust the electron distribution. A study carried out by Liu et al. [54] implanted sulfiphilic single atomic cobalt in lithiophilic heteroatom-doped carbon (SACo@HC) matrix, realizing the modulation of Co coordination atoms with a CoN3S structure, which was further verified by aberration corrected transmission electron microscope (AC-TEM) and X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectra (Fig. 3c). The assembled S-SACo@HC cathode exhibits encouraging rate performance of 745.9 mA h g−1 at 4.0 C. In situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), in situ Raman spectroscopy in combination with theoretical calculations further confirm that optimized CoN3S sites can effectively enhance the adsorption of polysulfides and thus accelerate the solid–liquid conversion in the redox reactions. As aforementioned, the generation and decomposition of Li2S is the decisive rate-determining step. Previous strategies typically deal with the use and modification of single-metal-centered SACs. As for the bidirectional Li2S redox process, the introduction of a bimetallic center is likely to introduce supplementary catalytic site, thereby providing a “qualitative” leap in the bidirectional catalysis of the redox process. Based on this, Sun et al. [55] proposed to apply the diatomic catalysts (DACs) with Fe-Co dual sites anchored on hollow carbon spheres (Fe-Co DACs) in Li–S batteries. Most metal atoms were found to exist in pairs with the aid of AC-TEM, with the distance between two atoms reaching about 2.5 nm (Fig. 3d). By further analyzing Fe-Co DACs via Fe and Co K-edge of X-ray absorption near-edge structure and X-ray absorption fine structure measurement, it is confirmed the successful synthesis of FeCo DACs in the coordination structure of N3Fe-CoN3. Throughout electrochemical tests and in situ characterizations, they indicated that Fe atom centers facilitate the acceleration of Li2S nucleation while Co centers contribute to the promotion of Li2S decomposition. The synergistic effects between FeCo DACs enable the assembled Li–S battery to exhibit a specific capacity of 688 mA h g−1 even at 5 C, while the capacity decay rate is only 0.018% after operating at 1 C for 1000 cycles. This study provides a paradigm for future related research. Nowadays, many efforts have been devoted to investigating the unique catalytic role of dual-atom catalysts in Li–S batteries. For example, Ding et al. [61] designed a Fe-Ni dual-atom moiety, which displays favorable catalytic performance by lowering the reaction barrier of the liquid–solid conversion step via the hybridization of the d-p orbitals. Impressively, the capacity decay rate of the assembled S@Fe-Ni-NG cathode was only 0.016% after 3000 cycles at 10.0 C. The separator in Li–S battery typically plays the role of ion conduction and electron insulation [62]. The widely used commercial separators are not effective in suppressing the shuttle effect. Therefore, researchers have developed separator modification strategies by coating different types of materials over commercial separators to optimize their performance [63,64]. The ubiquitous carbon materials require a high usage amount to achieve the desired performance owing to the low catalytic activity per unit mass, which greatly affects the ion conductive properties of the separator [51,65,66]. In the meantime, the non-polar adsorptive interaction between carbon materials and polysulfides seems not an effective means of restricting the shuttle effects. In comparison, SACs are known for theoretically achieving 100% atom utilization and having advanced catalytic activity per unit mass. Comparative performance can be gained with only a small amount of SACs. Being applied in separators, SACs can effectively limit the shuttling of polysulfides while improving the catalytic efficiency of redox kinetics without impeding the ion conductive features of the separator. MoS2 nanosheets have also been reported in separator modification. While such a modified separator could offer anchoring sites for polysulfides, it suffers from weak catalytic effect. In this sense, Dong et al. [67] designed polypropylene separators modified by MoS2 nanosheets with atomically dispersed nickel (Ni-MoS2). The introduction of Ni single atoms can further provide an abundance of catalytically active sites. The modified Ni-MoS2@PP separator achieves optimized adsorption of polysulfides and suppresses the shuttle effect simultaneously with accelerated reaction kinetics. As expected, the assembled Li–S batteries exhibit good electrochemical performance and durable stability. The capacity decay rate is as low as 0.01% per cycle after 400 cycles under 2 C. Even at a high sulfur loading of 7.5 mg cm−2, the battery still maintains an areal capacity of 5.9 mA h cm−2 after 50 cycles. Nowadays, strategies for enhancing the catalytic activity of SACs are mainly centered on substrate effects, high-loading regulation, coordination engineering and multi-metal center modulation. Table S1 in Supplementary Material summarizes the employment of single-atomic mediators at the cathode side of Li–S system. 2.2 Anode The challenges confronting the lithium anode stem mainly from the growth of lithium dendrites. Unlike uniformly deposited lithium, dendritic protrusions are likely to puncture the separator, causing short circuits of the battery, which is not conducive to its long-term operation [17]. Moreover, such a circumstance poses a great threat to the safety of the battery, which further hinders the commercialization of Li–S batteries. For this reason, considerable efforts have been devoted to tackling this thorny issue [68]. Typical approaches include physical limitations, such as using robust materials to mitigate the volume change of lithium during plating/stripping, or using an interlayer as a buffer [69] to prevent lithium dendrites from directly penetrating the separator. It was also indicated that the growth of lithium dendrites can be mitigated by dictating the deposition behavior of lithium. Owing to their unique electronic structure, single-atomic mediators exhibit outstanding ability to modulate the local electron density. Single atoms inherently have high surface free energy. When functioning as nucleation seeds, they have the potential to modulate lithium deposition process. Moreover, dispersed at the atomic scale, single-atomic mediators can provide more homogenous nucleation sites for lithium. Motivated by this, Xu et al. [70] proposed the application of Zn single-atom material (ZnSAs) for the protection of lithium anodes and explored the kinetic process of their induced lithium deposition. The surface energy of ZnSAs is lower than that of pristine graphene when bonded to Li atoms, implying that Li atoms prefer to bond to ZnSAs, as revealed by theoretical calculations. Additionally, the surface of ZnSAs also exhibits the lowest Li migration barrier, where Li tends to migrate to nearby areas instead of locally aggregating to form dendrites (Fig. 4 a). The above results indicate that the introduction of ZnSAs is beneficial to increasing the Li nucleation sites, reducing nucleation potential barrier and shortening the nucleation time. Electron microscopy and in situ optical microscopy further show the visualization results that Li is deposited in a homogeneous manner rather than forming dendrites. From the perspective of tailoring solvation structure, Wang et al. [75] elucidated the ingenious role of introducing “single-atom-in-defect” catalysts as interfacial catalyst layer for dendrite-free lithium deposition. Anchoring Fe single atoms in defect-rich cobalt sulfide nanoparticles and graphene supports, the abundant defects would stabilize the single atoms and promote their uniform distribution by modulating the electron density. This “SAC-in-defects” design lowers the barriers of Li+ desolvation and Li0 diffusion, enabling rapid Li+ generation to realize successive and uniform lithium deposition. Besides, some efforts are devoted to modifying single atoms on artificial interlayers. Huang et al. [71] designed Co–N x moiety coated on flexible carbon fiber skeleton as an artificial interlayer between lithium anode and the separator (Fig. 4b). The Co–N x -modified carbon skeleton converts from lithiophobic to lithiophilic, easing the growth of lithium dendrites by promoting the distribution of Li+ flux. When serving as an interlayer for sulfur cathode, Co-PCNF also exhibits impressive performance in expediting bidirectional conversion kinetics of sulfur moieties and inhibiting shuttle effect. 2.3 Usage in other metal–S batteries 2.3.1 Na–S battery Although the theoretical energy density (1274 W h kg−1) is inferior to that of Li–S batteries, the abundance of sodium resources renders Na–S batteries to stimulate extensive attention [76,77]. Akin to Li–S batteries, the development of Na–S batteries has been plagued by sluggish kinetics, polysulfide shuttle, and dendrite growth [78]. In light of this, Zhang et al. [72] used theoretical calculations to screen single atom yttrium sites for the bidirectional regulation of cathode and anode in Na–S batteries (Fig. 4c). Incorporated into the nitrogen-doped carbon host, Y–N4 units exhibit Janus properties. This Janus electrode can expedite the conversion of polysulfide and lower the decomposition potential barrier of Na2S at the cathode side. When used in the anode side, it can promote the high-dimensional sodium deposition and mitigate the dendrite growth. In addition, Jiang et al. [79] designed single atom vanadium anchored on a 3D nitrogen-doped hierarchical porous carbon matrix by first principles calculations, confirming the properties of isolated V sites for the adsorption and catalytic conversion of sodium polysulfide. 2.3.2 K–S battery Potassium–sulfur (K–S) batteries have also attracted a surge of interest due to high theoretical gravimetric energy density and abundant resource reserves [4,80,81]. However, the slow kinetic pathway between K2S3–K2S is a grand challenge [82]. The sluggish oxidation process of K2S during the charging process may lead to the formation of dead sulfur [83]. Such dead sulfur no longer participates in the subsequent reactions and therefore fails to contribute to the capacity, resulting in notable capacity loss. Ye et al. [73] proposed the use of Co single atoms as an effective mediator for the K2S oxidation process (Fig. 4d). The catalytic activity arises from the synergistic effect of CoS and NK interactions, allowing the dissociation of the KS bond. This study provides a paradigm for the application of SACs in K–S batteries. 2.3.3 Al–S battery In addition to the first main group metals (Li, Na, K), aluminum metal can also be utilized as the anode in metal–S batteries, which offer comparatively higher safety and favorable theoretical energy density (1340 W h kg−1) [4,84,85]. Ju et al. [74] investigated the different roles of single-atom iron catalysts dual-coordinated with N,O atoms (Fe-NO-C) in Li–S and Al–S batteries. During Li–S catalytic pathways, the highly electronegative oxygen coordination dampens the effect of d-p orbital hybridization between Fe-NO-C and S, consequently exhibiting a poor catalytic activity. In contrast, this inefficient d-p orbital hybridization in Al–S batteries is able to expedite Al–S conversion kinetics and boost bi-directional catalytic performance via polysulfide stabilization (Fig. 4e and f). This study sheds light on the design of single-atom coordination engineering in metal–sulfur batteries, enabling researchers to identify the different reaction mechanisms in Li–S and Al–S batteries. 2.4 Demand for single-atomic mediators in Li–S batteries The ultimate goal by using single-atomic mediators is to develop high-performance and high-safety Li–S batteries. Based on the above discussions, it is clear that each component faces distinct demands that need to be met (Fig. 5 ). A qualified sulfur cathode serves as a capacity contributor. The claim of SACs for cathode is expected to be able to effectively catalyze sulfur reactions and inhibit shuttle effect. Stability of the cathode is also a vital factor in the long-term cycling. As the battery operates, active sites may be covered by side-reaction products, or the catalyst itself might degrade. As for SACs, they are prone to form clusters during the reaction or dissolve in the electrolyte (demetallation), resulting in even fewer content [86]. In this regard, designing stable and robust SACs is worthwhile. The major requirements of SACs used in cathode should be predicted in terms of catalytic activity and stability. In light of the anode, the situation tends to be different. The affinity between the metal center and lithium metal is a decisive factor in dictating the behavior of lithium plating/stripping, making it worthy of consideration for the selection of the metal species [87]. Rather than simply increasing the loading of single atoms, it would be preferable to obtain uniformly dispersed single atoms to facilitate the uniform deposition of lithium metal. This calls for precise and controllable synthesis strategies. The development of uniformly dispersed single-atomic mediators has only been covered in few studies and is still at a nascent stage. 3 Synthetic strategies of single-atomic species It is noted that the overall activity of designed materials is quite sensitive to the synthetic method [88]. In this case, it is a challenging task to select a reliable route. A number of methodologies for the preparation of single-atomic species have been thoroughly discussed in previous review articles [38,39,89], including ball milling [40,90], atomic layer deposition [91] and wet chemistry [92,93]. Several issues of these methods have accordingly been identified. The ball milling route might produce materials with inhomogeneous size distribution where clusters are likely to be formed. A major drawback of atomic layer deposition lies in its high cost aspects and low yields, which somewhat hampers mass production. In contrast, CVD technique is an appealing method because of its good controllability, high quality, and large scalability [94,95]. In what follows, the CVD strategies and other emerging methods for the preparation of single atom species with demand-driven features are case studied, offering key perspectives for the rational design of single-atomic mediators for Li–S batteries. 3.1 Chemical vapor deposition CVD is a technique that employs chemicals in the gaseous or vapor state to form solid deposits over certain substrates by chemical reactions in the gas phase and/or at the gas–solid interface [96,97]. During the preparation of SAC materials by CVD, the metal atom sources are usually vaporized and transported in gaseous form to a specific substrate for reaction, followed by deposition on the substrate (Fig. 6 ). By simply adjusting the substrate, selecting the gas source, and/or manipulating the reaction time and temperature, multifarious materials could be prepared in high quality and purity. Given the flexibility and controllability of CVD method, it is widely used for the preparation of graphene [98,99] and related two-dimensional materials [100,101]. Wang et al. [102] prepared single iron atoms anchored on porous N-doped carbon (Fe-N-PC) by a two-step method. Iron acetylacetonate was adopted as the iron source, which was homogeneously dissolved in pyridine and subsequently vaporized. Under the transport of inert gas, Fe atoms would be deposited onto Mg(OH)2 templates placed in the tube. After the pyrolysis treatment, the Mg(OH)2 template could be removed using sulfuric acid to obtain Fe-N-C materials. Qiu et al. [103] designed single-atom Ni catalysts anchored to nanoporous graphene. Since nickel intrinsically dissolves easily in acidic systems, the hydrogen evolution performance of Ni-based catalysts in acidic systems could not be well maintained. In this regard, chemically stable graphene was chosen as a substrate to host Ni single atoms. The high HER activity of Ni and the stability of the graphene support were combined as an efficient and reliable catalyst for electrochemical hydrogen production. Specifically, after the reduction pretreatment of the nanoporous Ni substrate, graphene was grown on the substrate by CVD method. Subsequently, Ni-doped nanoporous graphene was obtained by treating the Ni substrate with hydrochloric acid. Although the above strategies have successfully rendered materials dispersed in the form of single atoms, they still rely on the use of acid to etch clusters during the preparation stage. Such a post-treatment would be complicated and resource-wasting. Considering this, it is imperative to develop a route for the growth of single atoms without subsequent treatment. Qu et al. [104] devised an ingenious emitting and trapping strategy to directly convert bulk copper into single atomic Cu sites supported on nitrogen-doped carbon (Cu-SAs/N-C) (Fig. 7 a). In their design, they used ammonia as a transport gas. Lewis acid-base interactions between Cu and NH3 result in the formation of Cu(NH3) x , which extract Cu atoms from the bulk Cu surface to reach the substrate with gas transport. Pre-treated ZIF-8 with vacant zinc sites and abundant defects was placed in a porcelain boat downstream of a quartz tube. The Cu(NH3) x transported downstream was trapped by ZIF-8, resulting in the formation of isolated Cu sites. This gas migration approach is generic, allowing the preparation of a series of M−SAs/N-C (M = Co or Ni) by substituting metal bulk materials, while simultaneously demonstrating the possibility of large-scale production. Along with the universal applicability, CVD technology also shows potential for the synthesis of highly stable materials. It has been demonstrated that the design of in situ method can establish a strong interaction between the metal center and the substrate, thereby facilitating to upgrade the stability of the material and avoid deactivation within a short period of time. Han et al. [105] proposed the in situ synthesis of SACs on sub-stable materials by CVD (Fig. 7b). As an HER electrocatalyst, the enhancement of catalytic activity of metallic tungsten disulfide (WS2) monolayers is still constrained by the high proportion of inactive basal plane of 2H phase. Despite many efforts devoted to enhancing the proportion of 1 T phase, the prepared WS2 is usually a two-phase mixture and is unstable when exposed to air for a long time. In this sense, they proposed a “two-in-one” strategy by introducing vanadium atomic dispersions as additional active sites while enhancing the proportion of 1 T phase for WS2. Highly dispersed vanadium atoms were successfully demonstrated on 1 T-WS2 monolayers (denoted as V SACs@1T-WS2) by one-step CVD. The as-synthesized materials display a high 1 T proportion of up to 91% and impressive HER performance, representing a new avenue for the direct synthesis of SACs as efficient and robust electrocatalysts over sub-stable materials. To devise ORR and HER electrocatalysts, metal single atoms are normally designed to coordinate with defects or heteroatoms on the carbon substrate to form metal-N x -C y moieties [108,109]. However, this is not the case in OER, as such moieties may cause insufficient catalytic activity and poor durability. With their unique metal-like electronic properties, tungsten carbide materials interact with metal centers, forming interactions similar to metal–metal bonds. Therefore, Li et al. [106] proposed to stabilize FeNi atoms on WC x supports via CVD to form Fe/NiW or Fe/NiC bonds (Fig. 7c), thus rendering sufficient stability to the supported FeNi atoms. Different coordination structures of the metal center sites have distinct stability or catalytic activity. Promoting the formation of highly stable sites contributes to the enhancement of overall durability. Such a purpose can be achieved by CVD technology. For example, the coordination form of FeN4 contains Fe centers in two types of coordination environments. One is a FeN4C12 moiety coordinated with four pyrrolic N atoms, the other is a FeN4C10 moiety with four pyridinic N ligands. The FeN4C12 site is more intrinsically active, with a tendency to be deactivated into iron oxides during the ORR process. In contrast, FeN4C10 sites are more stable during the reaction but with relatively low catalytic activity. Therefore, Liu et al. [107] devised a CVD route to release N/C species at high temperature from ZIF-8 nanocrystals and gradually deposited onto Fe–AC catalyst downstream of the tube furnace (Fig. 7d). This approach allows the deposition of a thin N-doped carbon layer on the Fe–AC surface, which improves the overall stability of the material by increasing a considerable percentage of FeN4C10 sites. SAC theoretically features 100% atom utilization, but sometimes this is not the case. When SACs are mostly buried in the interior of the substrate rather than dispersed on the surface, it would become a challenge for them to catalyze the reaction effectively. Designing SACs with active site exposure holds great promise. During the CVD process, the gas is usually transported to the substrate surface and bonded to surface atoms, under which circumstances it is prone to achieving the exposure of single atoms on the surface. This was reflected by Zhao et al. [110] to prepare single-Ni atoms decorated hollow S/N-doped football-like carbon spheres (Ni SAs@S/N-FCS) (Fig. 8 a). The final Ni SAs@S/N-FCS were generated by NiCl2 as the metal source and the Ni atoms were trapped on the outer surface of the substrate by gas phase migration. As for the work by Jiao et al. [111], they designed an atomic substitution strategy by using FeCl3 as the gas source and replacing the Zn atoms from the Zn–N–C sites with Fe atoms (Fig. 8b). The Fe–N4 sites generated under high-temperature trans-metalation are accessible by air, contributing to high utilization. The CVD method also enables universal preparation throughout flexible substrate replacement. Liu et al. [112] proposed a generic CVD strategy for the preparation of SACs, where a metal-doped ZnO is served as a substrate, followed by gaseous 2-methylimidazole transport and subsequent deposition (Fig. 8c). After heat treatment of the substrate, atomically dispersed metal SACs are obtained. This universal strategy exhibits simplicity by requiring only the desired metal doping into the ZnO template. 3.2 Other emerging strategies With the ever-increasing research on SACs in versatile fields, there is an emerging variety of preparation methods. This section provides a demand-oriented classification of other emerging strategies for SAC design. 3.2.1 Preparing highly loaded SACs The loading of SACs is commonly less than 5 wt%. Although low content of single atoms also demonstrates good catalytic performance, researchers are still pursuing ways to increase the loading toward future commercialization. Jiang et al. [113] proposed an interfacial assembly strategy to achieve 7.9 wt% loading by constructing nanocage structures to confine binary single-atom Fe-/Co-N x in porous shells (Fig. 9 a). More surprisingly, a record of 41.8 wt% single atom content was made. It was achieved by a laser planting strategy reported by Wang et al. [117]. Specifically, they achieved ultra-high single-atom loadings by decomposing precursors into single atoms and anchoring them into the defects generated by laser pulses. 3.2.2 Fabricating highly stable SACs Deactivation of single-atomic active sites is a pitfall affecting the long-term cycling. In fact, reliable synthesis strategies play a fundamental role in the stability of single atoms. Apart from in situ synthesis strategies such as CVD, encapsulation method constructs a solid and reliable shell for active sites with the confinement of single atoms into a specific molecular cage. Common encapsulation methods include the use of cage materials such as metal organic frameworks (MOF) [118–121] and covalent organic frameworks (COF) [122,123] to confine metal atoms within a specific framework to achieve atomic-level dispersion. Chen et al. [114] chose sodalite (SOD) within Y zeolite as a cage and utilized template molecules to occupy supercages, after which the Pt species were confined to it and subsequently processed to form Pt single atoms (Fig. 9b). By virtue of the unique coordination environment of Pt single atoms encapsulated within such SOD cages, Pt@Y-SOD exhibits not only good catalytic activity but also resistance to thiophene and CO poisoning, contributing to the enhancement of SACs lifetime. 3.2.3 Controllable synthesis of SACs The migration behavior of single atoms during the preparation is often uncontrollable, leading to the formation of clusters or uneven distribution. In addition, it is challenging to keep the single atom loading to a certain amount. The content of single atoms tends to vary from batch to batch, either at high or low levels. Therefore, with the development of technology, it is imperative to design a precisely controlled synthesis strategy. Shi et al. [115] proposed the use of underpotential deposition for the preparation of metal single atoms, which has a self-terminating effect, as compared to conventional electrochemical deposition (Fig. 9c). The self-terminating growth effect means that even if the deposition time and metal precursor concentration increase, when the surface-limited reaction reaches saturation, the continued growth of metal atoms into clusters is automatically halted, thus always limiting the deposition of metals to the atomic scale. Fu et al. [124] developed a laser ablation strategy to achieve precise tuning of Pt nanoparticles to Pt single atom conversion on CeO2. By setting different laser powers and irradiation times, the ratio of Pt single atoms can be precisely controlled between 0 and 100%. 3.2.4 Room-temperature synthesis of SACs The preparation of single atoms usually requires elevated temperature and pressure conditions in a harsh environment [125], resulting in a large energy consumption and high cost aspect. In this regard, developing synthetic methods to allow preparation under mild conditions such as in ambient temperature and pressure is meaningful. Wang et al. [116] proposed an electrofiltration method for the synthesis of SACs at room temperature (Fig. 9d). Specifically, the graphene oxide membrane has the characteristics of narrow interlayer spacing, large number of layers and few cracks. When Fe atoms lose electrons into Fe2+ and migrate out of the bulk iron, it can greatly reduce the diffusion rate of Fe2+ while blocking most of their migration, acting as a filter-like effect. The concentration of Fe2+ reaching around the working electrode is very low, which prevents the nuclei from growing and thus aggregating into metal. Besides, the photodeposition strategy at atmospheric temperature and pressure was also reported by Liu et al. [126], with respect to the synthesis of single atom Ag-N3S1 catalysts with asymmetric sites. 4 Conclusions and perspectives In summary, this paper provides an overview of the designing philosophy of single-atomic mediators and their main applications in Li–S batteries. The emerging preparation techniques represented by CVD are also discussed in detail. It is noted that the bonding of single atoms to sulfur species relies primarily on the hybridization, where metal center provides d orbital to hybridize with the p orbital of the sulfur-containing species. The hybridization effect gives rise to energy level splitting orbitals, including bonding and anti-bonding orbitals. As the electrons gradually occupy from lower to higher energy levels, the anti-bonding orbitals become progressively full. Therefore, the less electron filling is favorable to increase the degree of d-p orbital hybridization and enhance the catalytic activity. Single-atomic mediators exert versatile impacts in a Li–S battery. At the cathode side, they can effectively expedite the redox kinetics and optimize the adsorption behaviors of polysulfide intermediates, resulting in mitigation of the shuttle effect. Considering that single-atomic mediators mainly play a catalytic role on the cathode side, it is critical to enhance their catalytic activity. Modulation strategies, such as loading optimization, coordination environment engineering, and multi-metal center coupling, could be implemented to upgrade the catalytic activity. The intractable problem at the anode is the growth of lithium dendrites, hence the application of single atoms aims to effectively manage the deposition behavior of lithium metal and homogenize the nucleation sites to alleviate this issue. By virtue of its controllability and flexibility, CVD technology is gradually deployed for the preparation of SACs with specific features. The in situ CVD synthesis strategy can stabilize metal atoms over the support by bonding them to the substrate surface atoms, enhancing the long-term stability of the material and avoiding troublesome treatments such as acid etching. In addition, a wide range of desired SACs are accessible by a simple replacement of the substrate or metal gas source, which has the merits of universality and scalability, offering possibilities for the practical usage of the CVD-enabled single atom materials. Despite the undoubted fact that SACs have shown eye-catching potential in Li–S batteries, this field is still not mature with many existing challenges waiting to be addressed. With the goal of advancing the development of SACs in Li–S chemistry, the following directions for future research could be pursued (Fig. 10 ): (1) Constructing the SAC library. The design of single atom materials is usually based on a “trial-and-error” approach. The catalytic performance of different metal centers, ligand environments, substrates, and loading content in Li–S catalysis cannot be compared with the control variables, rendering it challenging to effectively select SACs for different systems. Many studies have been limited to certain transition metals such as Fe, Co, Ni, with random studies for other metal types. Therefore, the construction of SAC library for Li–S catalysis is a significant reference for future research in related fields. Specifically, it would be worthwhile to develop universal strategies to modulate different metal centers or to modify the coordination structure of metal atoms. Proposing uniform evaluation criteria or descriptors to assess the catalytic activity of a series of single atoms is also meaningful. (2) Exploring functional mechanism of SACs. The reactions in Li–S batteries contain complex intermediates and multiphase transformations, and thus separate catalytic mechanisms are often involved in different intermediate reactions. Further study of the catalytic mechanism of SACs in Li–S batteries at the atomic/electronic scale can help us to grasp rate-determining steps and clear active sites in the reactions, so as to develop higher energy density Li–S batteries. (3) Implementation of advanced characterization techniques. The prevailing techniques employed to characterize single atoms are mainly HAADF-STEM and synchrotron radiation, from the results of which the information on the atomic level dispersion and coordination environment of single atoms can be analyzed. However, reaction processes involving changing intermediates and complex reaction pathways are not invariant. Some intermediates may be transient, which requires the use of advanced in situ techniques for real-time observation. The application of state-of-art techniques helps to define the mechanisms of single atoms in synthetic and catalytic processes, enabling better targeting of these issues for refinement. (4) Probing deactivation mechanisms and protection strategies of SACs. With the continuous progress of reactions, active sites fail to play their catalytic roles piece by piece. Eventually, they will lose activity, which is macroscopically manifested as the degradation of battery performance or even short circuit. For now, few studies have noticed the change of active sites. On one hand, it could be the deactivation of the single atom itself after agglomeration, or that the active sites were covered by reaction by-products, making it difficult to contact the reactants. Another possibility is that the single-atom undergoes irreversible side reactions during the catalytic process. Protection strategies include, but are not limited to, the enhancement of stability, the provision of protective media, and the introduction of by-product eliminators. All these deserve further exploration for developing long-term Li–S batteries. coredata.dc:description: Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries have attracted considerable attention as one of the most appealing energy storage systems. Strenuous efforts have been devoted to tackling the tremendous challenges, mainly pertaining to the severe shuttle effect, sluggish redox kinetics and lithium dendritic growth. Single-atomic mediators as promising candidates exhibit impressive performance in addressing these intractable issues. Related research often utilizes a trial-and-error approach, proposing solutions to fabricate single-atomic materials with diversified features. However, comprehensive review articles especially targeting demand-driven preparation are still in a nascent stage. Inspired by these considerations, this review summarizes the design of single-atomic mediators based on the application case-studies in Li–S batteries and other metal–sulfur systems. Emerging preparation routes represented by chemical vapor deposition technology are introduced in a demand-oriented classification. Finally, future research directions are proposed to foster the advancement of single-atomic mediators in Li–S realm.
